title: Why Rebar Makes Concrete Indestructible
description: One-minute skill: Why Rebar Makes Concrete Indestructible.

hook.text: Concrete is great at compression but terrible in tension. It cracks when you bend or pull it. Rebar fixes this.

buildup.text: Compression pushes material together. Tension pulls apart. Concrete handles 10x more push than pullâ€”strong but brittle.

discovery.text: Steel excels in tensionâ€”it bends without snapping. Steel bars inside concrete give it the pull resistance it lacks.

twist.text: It works because steel and concrete expand at nearly the same rate with heat. Mismatched rates would crack the bond.

climax.text: Rebar made high-rises, bridges, and dams possible. Without it, concrete can only build short, gravity-loaded structures.

punchline.text: Steel handles the pull. Concrete handles the push.

quiz.question: Why do steel and concrete work so well together structurally?
options: They expand at nearly the same rate and complement each other's strengths
Steel is embedded only for fire protection purposes
Concrete bonds chemically with the steel, creating a new alloy
